threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

last_replies.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

What causes print supports on Ender 3 V2 to just fuse into the print and can't be removed?

I've tried support settings in both cura and prusaslicer. 205 c, pla, 60c bed. Only thing I have yet to do is a pid temp tuning. Could that be it?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2511438
>What causes print supports on Ender 3 V2 to just fuse into the print and can't be removed?
The supports were extruded too close to the print and achieved fusion rather than cold lap. The parameter is called contact distance in Pusaslicer. You can also lower the temp, but that's undesirable since that also reduces desired layer fusion.

Here we discuss microcontrollers, SBCs and microcontroller accessories, such as Atmel mega and tiny AVRs (Arduinos), PICs, ARM boards such as blue/black pill STM32, ESP8266/32s, Raspberry Pi, and others.

For general electronics questions (power supplies, level shifting, motor driving, etc.) please ask /ohm/.

>where can I find verified quality microcontrollers and other electronic sensors or parts
digikey.com
mouser.com
arrow.com
newark.com

>but that's too expensive
aliexpress.com (many parts here are fake, particularly specific parts out of stock in the above sites)
lcsc.com

>I need a part that does X and Y, with Z specifications. How can I find it?
use digikey or mouser's parametric part search. Then purchase from one of the sellers listed above.

>how do I get started with microcontrollers, where should I start?
There is no defined starting point, grab a book and start reading or buy an arduino off ebay/amazon and start messing around. There are a plethora of examples online to get started.

Along the lines of what this fella said:

Cut open an unneeded tube, put a little bit of rock tumbler grit in, and leave the tube turning on rollers for a day or so. See if it removes some of the coating. Keep in mind you could roll it for much longer if it is partially successful.

If it works, maybe we can figure out a way to insert some grit without unsealing the tube. Perhaps score the tube in a circumference at one end, and enclose the score in a wide rubber band with some grit under it. Crack the tube and wiggle the joint so some grit enters.

It may be that you need to reinforce the tube on either side of the score beforehand. Epoxy some steel rings on or such. Put the rubber band over the rings, and you'd have a nice channel between them to fill with grit.

I don't know if rubber is permeable to the gases within the tube... but you get the idea, I hope.

Op this part is a bit confusing from both a design and manufacturing point of view.

>>2504465
The areas this poster highlighted are why this part is troublesome.

Why did you put a radius on that face of the teeth? (Red)
Why did you create a sharp obtuse angle where the teeth connect? (Green)

If these features are not totally necessary, or could be removed by altering a different part of your build, your part would be much easier to machine.

Also your tolerance of +/- 0.1mm for the whole part is kind of showing your inexperience. For this part to do what I think it's doing, you only need that level of precision on four features, the outer diameter circularity and runout, and the location of your holes. That is assuming a massive rpm that actually requires that precision. 0.1mm (.0039in) or what a machinist would call "four thou"(sand) is like Intel circuit board or Ferrari cylinder precision. You could probably loosen that up to 0.010in, which will also make your part much more doable for average machine shops running this kind of a part on a 3 axis HAAS.

As it stands this part well require 5 axis machining and cost thousands of dollars.
If you can remove the face radius, and add an end mill friendly radius to your teeth connections, you could run this part on a 3 axis machine for less than a thousand.

t. Design ME

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2511252

Construction fag.

Fix the leak first. It's probably coming from the outside in. So check the exterior window for cracks and seams, and caulk them with a good exterior sealant.

For the drywall, you need to cut away any molded or soft material. Hard and strong drywall can stay.

With a small hole you can just use spackle and keep adding and then sanding until you get the result you need. But with larger hole you need a replacement piece of drywall that you fit into the hole and use the tape and stuff, etc.

When you use a replacement patch of drywall you either need to drill into a stud, or cheat by attaching 2 boards behind the drywall then attaching to the boards you added.

Tell me if this is a worthwhile idea
I have a gas 40 gallon water heater that is 18 years old.
It came with the house I bought
I have well water and I recently installed an iron and a 5 micron whole house filter
The water heater is dirty, I've flushed it twice so far, and cant get all the crap out of it.
I want a tankless heater, but i'll settle for an 80 gallon when this thing blows.
That being said, and since this thing is at the end of its useful life, is it worth cleaning it further?
I want to remove it, take outside, fill it with CLR, hang it on a tree, and agitate it, and flush it out clean.
New water heater is not in my budget right now, I just want clean hot water so I can fill a bath with the wife.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2511150
>but isnt that also true for a tank heater? a tank heater isnt heating the pipes either
Yes and no. It's more that the tankless doesn't have an appreciable thermal mass to it, unlike the tank, and even though it does heat up pretty quickly it's still initially running ground-temp water through it. So I find if I have maybe 30 minutes of time between uses of the kitchen faucet the water on the hot side will be cold again for a bit.
The brand that was recommended by the plumber I dealt with was Navien which has a stainless steel heat exchanger. There's another company called NTI which was recommended by another plumber which has an aluminum exchanger which the one that I went with felt was mid-range. Both had built-in recirculation pumps and could handle heating the house as well as the potable water (often called a combi-boiler as opposed to a tankless water heater). Neither of them recommended Rinnai, and as I said I had other financial issues which caused me to just replace the furnace instead of refitting the house for hydronic (bit of a shame as they're the equivalent of a 98+ furnace so my heating costs would be maybe half or less what they are today) so I can't say how it would have done. When the tankless finally goes (sometime within the next ten years I'd wager), I intend to replace it with a combi with recirc and look at the hydronic again.

On a hot water heater that's spent 18 years on a well water system, the tank inside is probably comprised solely of rust. Any attempts to clean the tank, especially with rust removers, I would say is more likely to cause it to develop leaks than if you had just left it alone.

On a related note, if/when you go to replace it, if you're going to use another tank style heater get one of the non-metallic plastic ones (such as a Rheem Marathon) as they're far less susceptible to the rust/corrosion common with well water systems.

threads.com: I work as an office wagie in a manufacturing environment, and I often work with engineers and our maintenance crew. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2511062
Take a machining course or a mechatronics course to begin with. Welding helps greatly. The reason for formal training is to speed up your early learning and expose you to theory of operation.

Many machinists become millwrights because the money is better. Talk to actual millwrights in your country to see what specific quals they want in a noob. There is no substitute for communication.

If serious ask if you can be a helper on night shift then stay late to learn. That makes you very impressive to any sane employer. I've done that several times to learn useful skills and it pays off.

You can at least easily buy the Makita power tools that are made in Japan. In Australia all I can find is the stuff that's made in China, with my one non-brushless tool made in Thailand.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
avoid brushed if you can, especially for cordless tools. they use a lot more power.

i would recommend buying a few tools in one specific make/brand/lineup and expanding as-needed, and look for bundles that include batteries. when my wife and I moved-in together, she had an 18v Makita drill with 2 batteries... and that was it. Now we have two drills, plus an impact/hammer, oscillating multitool, flashlight and 10in saw and 5 batteries (some are 8 years old and still work great), including a bigass 5amp one. We use all of these frequently and they have each individually paid for themselves multiple times over in utility.

I assess the value of tools on an as-needed basis. For instance, wife and I needed a finishing nailgun in order to install some baseboards. Makita cordless one plus battery was something stupid like $199... for a tool we would maybe use a few times. For that cost, we got a 5gal air compressor (something i've wanted) and cheap nailgun that got the job done from harbor freight (lmao) for basically half the cost. Will probably seldom need it again, but it is there and it was cheap.

Yard tools are Ryobi. Quality is shit, old home owner left them with the house though so we use them... they work but they're like green plastic toys.

You can't really go wrong with DeWalt/Makita/Milwaukee. Once you get into one ecosystem though it makes sense to stick with it, so consider carefully before you dump $600 on brushed equipment that you might not like many years down the line. Better to get a few, good tools now and expand later.

threads.com: I’m going to be doing some work 20ft up in the air on the side of this guys house. I have an extension ladder. What are some dos and don’ts of using an extension ladder safely??

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510166
I've always stuck by the rule that the acceptable diagonal slope is determined by
this:
Stand with your lowest rung touching your legs. Reach out with your arms, and if the ladder is farther than your arms are long, it's too far slanted. If it's closer than your elbow it's too straight.
ALWAYS have one hand on a rung
been painting exteriors for 10+ years and I've never fallen off a ladder (skipping the last rung going down doesn't count :) )

Make sure feet of ladder are secured, and that both the left and the right of the top of the ladder are bracing against something sturdy
(as opposed to either side dangling in the air) Yes, I've seen it happen with some cheap ass fucks
Never ever ever put ladder against windows

To test ladder won't fall away from you on a hill,
put it down the way you want, step up one to two rungs, then jump a few times putting your entire weight on to see if it moves.
Let someone know you're on a ladder so they can be nearby if you fall.

I have an ancient gas oven that's set up to run on a propane tank out back. The stovetop works but the oven part does not. Everything in it is mechanical except the clock and the spark wires that light the gas, so it's not an electrical problem. The gas flow is good enough to light all four stovetop burners on full blast simultaneously.
Inside, when I turn on the oven, it clicks and lights the pilot. The pilot flame comes on after a concerningly long amount of clicking (which I attribute to mice chewing on the wires to the spark), but the rest of the pipe never lights. It is equipped with a mercury capillary-driven safety valve with a bulb over the pilot light, so if the pilot goes out the gas will stop. I have confirmed the safety valve works by removing it, holding a lighter to the bulb, and blowing through where the propane goes. After about 10 seconds of heat on the bulb I can feel it suddenly open up and air comes out where it's meant to. The main pipe the oven flames are supposed to come from is not clogged, it's not even dirty.
It does have a regulator on the back, which I have never touched. I've read online that in many cases the regulator is just for the oven part and if it fails the stovetop will still work. How can I test if the regulator is bad without buying a new one, since it's practically antique? I am soliciting any other ideas for what could be wrong with this thing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508340
LP gas requires a minimum of 10"wc (that's water column, NOT psi) inlet pressure and should be set to somewhere in the neighborhood of 7"wc output.

If this was originally a natural gas stove then it would also require you to change all of the burner orifices and the pilot orifice. Natural gas orifices are larger and allow more gas flow, if you put LP through them at the correct pressure it will seriously overfire and soot up. Good luck finding LP orifices for a stove since they usually are made for a specific gas and the mfg doesn't sell conversion kits.

tl;dr pressure too low cause you eyeballed it

People are oversimplifying the answering
If you try to put a tiny current through a big wire, it will actually be met with way more resistance than a small wire as the current lacks direction so it can wander around the oversized highway instead of going straight through

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2508726
>>2510784
>>2509145
Jesus christ. for the purposes of any real conversation DC current flows through the entire cross-section of the conductor. We can be autistic about Maxwell equations all day long about how a conductor cannot have electric field and whatnot, but to go back to the hydraulic analogy that's practically the same thing as arguing that water doesn't flow in a pipe, the pipe just sets the boundaries.

Now, if you were to have a long large diameter wire and a short small diameter wire so that they have equal resistance, and applied the same voltage to them, the larger wire would in fact have the electrons moving slower, but there's more of them so the overall current is the same. In semiconductors (possibly all materials, only really relevant in semiconductors afaik), you will actually run into the limit of the electron drift velocity where increasing voltage does not increase current because the electrons cannot move any faster due to interacting with other shit in the atomic structure

>>2510119
Unironically this is your solution.

Rack that folds up onto the wall, vertical plate storage and a barbell stand/wall hooks. Add on a folding weight bench and maybe a diy rolling adjustable dumbell cart (that also uses 2" olympic plates to minimize equipment) and you can fit your entire workout station in the space of a wardrobe.

For the workshop you buy/build a workbench with some casters on the feet so it can be rolled out of the way for the workout. Alternatively, have the workbench fold up/down against the wall via hinges, but this requires the bench be completely cleared off to move which is annoying.

For reference, I planned an olympic workout space + office space to fit into the 8'x7.25' section of a tinyhouse. My circumstances required a fair bit of custom made stuff to fit together like puzzle pieces for such a small space, but a few extra feet give you a lot more freedom for off-the-shelf equipment. Overhead and wall storage really help alleviate storage issues.

At that size, why are batteries used instead of a diesel-powered generator? Or are they normally used in a tiered system to provide instant power while a generator comes online? last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510963
>I'm sure there's a use case, I'm just curious what it is.
You hit it here:
>Or are they normally used in a tiered system to provide instant power while a generator comes online?
And reduced maintenance costs. Even a pre-heated, continuously oiled, air start diesel generator has a non trivial time between the call for backup electricity and the ability to accept 100% of the rated load. As an example, nuclear plants that use literal train engines as their back-up power source when there is a loss-of-offsite-power plan for 15-45 seconds of time between the reactor trip and the diesel engines picking up all the house loads at 100%. Everything that needs to stay up during the transient is on a UPS. They are also one of the most maintenance intensive items in a nuclear plant.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507235
Put on forcefield or zip system sheathing
Then if you're north of Missouri, nail on 2x2s and put 1.5" foam insulation in-between the nailers

Then side with cement siding for sound dampening or vinyl with a smaller slat so it's 0 maintenance

You want to put on sheathing to hold the house square, which acts as a moisture barrier for comfort in the home and then a wind barrier (the film on the outside of the sheathing) which also allows condensation to run down

The 1.5" of insulation will ensure minimal condensation inside the house.
If you're doing a moisture barrier inside, then a moisture barrier outside (plain plywood/OSB technically counts) is SUPER FUCKING IMPORTANT or your walls will rot after 3 years

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510771
Reason not to do this is that a beat to shit poorly maintained rental with 300k on it would be a nightmare to fix and maintain. I used to drive Ryder trucks when my fleet truck was cooked and let me tell you, those gears were sooo fucking sloppy and they always had something leaking. If it's based off a platform with continuing support replacing drivetrain is a option though.

Personally if I was going to get a ex-fleet vehicle to live in, I'd pick a school bus. Lots more space than 26ft box truck, has built in man doors. Very strong bodies, busses are designed to keep unbelted children safe when they get t-boned. Depending on district most places cycle busses out when they hit 300k or when they hit 20~ years of age, typically age first if it's inner city, those machines don't travel far. Ritzy private schools often cycle them out much quicker, not uncommon to see a 10y/o bus with 80-k on the clock up for auction. License is dead easy to get, if you're too dumb to get it you're too retarded to DIY a place to live. Most of them are autos which saves them from most user error/abuse, all have commonly available diesel engines like caterpillar, detroit, etc. so ANY diesel shop can fix em if you can't. Worst case scenario you can drop in a new engine/trans of ANY brand, the bodies and drive trains are made separately then assembled when a fleet orders o there's a lot of interoperability, whether new new or from a wrecked big rig, box truck or school bus. Most have air brakes though, I personally prefer air brakes for a large commercial-sized vehicle for the reliability and backup they offer, but if that's a sticking point for you some districts use hydraulics. Buy one from a area that doesn't get real winters IE Arizona to limit rust. If you're in a area that gets winter have her undercoated and keep it clean and the body will last forever.

>t. used to drive school busses, currently drive big rigs. North American perspective, no idea about down under

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509645
That sounds like your alignment is good, what direction do you have the outer insert pointing towards?

>now it's a little less than a thou over 6 inches from the pocket face
This probably goes without saying, but you are checking this with a known straight tool shank or test bar and as short of an indicator setup as you can get right? The body of the drill isn't supposed to be centered in the hole, if you find center using an indicator from the outer insert to the opposite side of the body it will drill small and you'll have chip issues, there's supposed to be 0.010-0.020" of clearance on the non cutting side.


>C12L14 cold roll, ~1krpm and .003
Without a size I can only really guess, that would be about right for a 2-2.5" drill, do you have any idea what insert grade(s) you're using? With the Sandvik tools and I'm used to and a good general purpose insert, I'd aim for 600-700SFM at a 0.0015-0.002" IPR feed as a starting point, once you get one hole done you can evaluate changes based on the insert condition, feed would be the first thing I'd try to increase. Most of my experience is with specialty HSLA steels and high performance nickel alloys, having some 12L14 for a day would be a pleasant dream, but I don't have any direct experience.

The thing I like to keep in mind is that they're not "drills" in the common sense, it's more like a boring bar that can take a massive cut since the loads are not symmetrically balanced, you've got to throw out a lot of the conventional logic. When they're running correctly they should sound about like this https://youtu.be/0N9ktwuNH9k?t=31 but almost ear piercingly loud, you probably want some form of ear pro when you're using one.

If your house is at 50 and your pipes freeze it's your own fault. Any supply pipes in unconditioned spaces should be insulated and/or have heat tape on them.
Despite what the average knuckle dragger thinks, your pipes do not spontaneously explode the moment it gets to 32 inside. All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 2022-11-19]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Bambu Labs X1
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Rat Rig, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2510211
Nah man vaseline is risky. All hydro-carbon chemicals have a chance to be absorbed by certain plastics because they are hydro-carbon products of petroleum themselves. There is no good way to tell which lubricant will attack which plastic other than empirical, destructive testing. That's why "PTFE, silicone, or graphite" are recommended because they aren't hyrdo-carbons and the chance of this freak interaction occurring is extremely low. If you can't find these plastic-safe lubes, it's better to just not lube them since plastics are often self-lubricating like other anons said.

>>2508029
>>must add a quart of werewolf tears every six and a half moons otherwise the anaerobic ghost will come haunt you
checked and accurate
Are you not doing this? Holy fuck.

What you're doing is essentially what my father did growing up. All forms of throwing your compostable stuff to the ground and letting it rot and dissolve into the earth is ok, but if you want to have a super-rich soil load every year, composting it in place is best. Turning it over is necessary and if you want to avoid concentrations of certain bacteria, you want to avoid tossing in fats and citrus and a few other things.

THAT said, I used an anaerobic compost barrel last year and produced EXCELLENT fertilizer by tossing all yard waste into a barrel of water and stirring once a week. Smells like an unwashed asshole, but when I applied it, I got the explosive growth I was promised. Additionally, I use an aerobic compost tumbler for my kitchen waste.

My garden kicks ass every year.

Sometimes doing the bare minimum is effective, but not the most beneficial.

last_replies.com:
>>2509928
>What's the difference, in a single day, between having an fixed panel (tilted to optimal angle) vs having an active tracking setup?
Well, even on a fixed setup at home it has its benefits, you're going to have a better power output in the end. Check "solar tracking system" on Youtube. But these giant things are probably pretty pricey so yeah, manually tilting the solar panels at the ideal angle for your location and time of the year is the common practice that is good enough and cheap.

The thing is that this is going to be a trailer hauled by an eBike travelling around Europe, and what might be the optimal angle on the first mile/km of your day can at any turn become the opposite: a completely shitty angle, all depending on the varying directions you're going in throughout the day.
"So just have the solar panel flat all the time so that it's good enough in all directions" : sure, that's what most people do on moving vehicles / solar bikes.
But if you have the time and money to make a small system that can have the best angle at all time and all directions, why not go for that? In the end that's extra mileage, it's totally worth it imo. + it's going to be a fun project messing around with the Arduino modules and stuff, I'll learn a lot and in the end and when everything will work it will look good.

Look at what this guy did and you'll see what I'm talking about. This is basically a way more complicated and expensive system than what I'm going to do, but it does look good
https://www.youtube.com/@solarEbike

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2509928
>>2509944
>Then adjust the thing by hand (wing nut, threaded knob, etc).
This is exactly what I planned on doing at first, manual adjustment with lock pins, clamp lever or whatnot, just like these guys did:
https://youtu.be/k8MbGucbUwo?list=PLvsZOwlnh4bXnXjfFiRusy1nrjzdk5rWY&t=297
So basically have the panels flat when you're riding and once you stop at camp or for a break, manually tilt the solar panel at the ideal angle.
But then I thought why not automate it all so that you have the perfect angle even while you're riding? Once again I have the time, the will, the money (it's not even that much extra money, you just need an Arduino with some modules and a linear actuator) and I'm going to learn a ton of stuff during the process. And you end up with better power output, so it's all benefits to me. I'm eager to get started honestly.

What do you guys like for modern production environment design?

I found this firm in my country that uses stainless tubes to configure all sorts of tables, carts etc. Also there's MayTec and Bosch/Rexroth that use mostly extruded aluminium profiles, these two also have their own CAD software to allow quick configuration of all sorts of setups, which is nice.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I work at a Toyota subsidiary, and we use Toyota Production System (many influences on modern lean ideas). I'm in the US.
We use a huge amount of the pipe & joint stuff. The same kind of thing you reference as "stainless tubes". Vendor lock-in is the unfortunate reality. For the first few years we sourced stuff from Creform, then switched to PAC. That second compnay does not show up readily in search results unless you search the full name 'Production Automation Corporation'. Same size parts are generally interchangeable, but the fit is off--like putting together LEGO and MegaBloks.

One advantage for this kind of system is that reworking a station, cart, bench, etc takes one day, or an off-shift. It's easy and fast enough that you can iterate on designs. Just keep a cabinet with the most common parts, some extra tubes, etc. A big benefit for me is that the workers/users can do simple repairs/mods. If something is loose, or misaligned, or needs moved 1" to the left, they can do it with a set of hex keys. If you know someone isn't a retard, you can also give them a tubing cutter & deburr tool--lete them do the work vs trying to explain it.

Last, I'll mention that we did some test setups with 80 20 aluminum extrusion. One guy had a hardon for it. I'm pretty sure it's on the "We tried it, and it doesn't hold up the like steel tubes do" list forever.

last_replies.com:
What i've discovered after having some heavy rain on a recently erected prefab:
>tannalised / pressure treated wood is a must
>avoid shitlap and go for tongue and groove
>be generous with weather resistant paint
>fill any huge interior gaps with weather resistant expanding foam and trim as needed
>fill any joints between panels and exterior gaps with weather resistant sillicone sealant or similar
>install regular house size guttering
>have good concrete paving foundation raised above ground level by an inch or two
>ensure that any hard ground / exposed foundation around the edges of the shed has either guttering above or somehting to deflect rainwater splashback away from the wood
>allow an inch or so in between the foundations and the floor of the shed for ventilation
